Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Three-Dimensional Analysis of the Gas and Dark Matter in the CLASH Clusters of Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will use their state-of-the-art model to analyze submillimeter, optical and X-ray observations of 25 clusters of galaxies. The model will reveal if the clusters are shaped like baseballs, cigars, pancakes or something more complex. Once the cluster shapes are known, the cluster masses will be estimated with unprecedented accuracy. This will give cosmologists a powerful new tool to study why the universe evolves as it does. The team will release their modeling code to the public. Senior team members will train junior members. The team will also develop free on-line teaching materials and interact with high school students in low-income areas.

The team will analyze extensive observations of clusters of galaxies to form three-dimensional reconstructions of their dark matter and gaseous matter. Inferences in three dimensions stem from differences in how the X-ray and Sunyaev-Zeldovich signals vary within a cluster. The reconstructions will vastly improve the accuracy of cluster-mass estimates. This, in turn, will improve cluster-based cosmology. The team's specific goals are to measure for each cluster (1) the major-axis orientation to +/-15 degrees and the axial ratio to +/-0.15; (2) the ratio of non-thermal to thermal pressures, achieving +/-0.2 in the outskirts; and (3) the three-dimensional mass profile, achieving +/-0.1 in the concentration parameter. To quantify the robustness of the measurements, the team will also evaluate (1), (2) and (3) for mock observations of simulated clusters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Author: Megan Donahue, Michigan State University
Title: Collaborative Research: A Three-Dimensional Analysis of the Gas and Dark Matter in the CLASH Clusters of Galaxies
Federal Award ID: 1613899
Report Submission Period: 07/01/2017 to 06/30/2018

The goal of our research project is to provide measurements of dark matter that can potentially tell us what dark matter is really made out of. We observe clusters of galaxies because they provide the best sources of information about dark matter.

Clusters of galaxies are the most massive, gravitationally-bound, systems in the universe. ("Super clusters" can be larger and potentially more massive, but those systems are not yet in gravitational equilibrium.) Astronomers have identified clusters of galaxies as groups of galaxies in visible-light images (glass plates and photographs). A cluster of galaxies may have hundreds of galaxies, all at a common distance from Earth. Each galaxy orbits the center of mass; often the most massive galaxy of the cluster is found at or near the center of the system. At Caltech  in the 1930s, Fritz Zwicky discovered that the orbits of galaxies within the clusters were too fast and large to be confined by the gravitational efforts of the stars in those galaxies. Either clusters of galaxies were temporary, expanding systems or something else, something that outweighed all of the stars put together, by a factor of 50!  -  called "dark matter" - was supplying the gravity needed to allow these orbits to persist.

Astronomers in the 1970s were surprised to discover that clusters of galaxies were also giant, diffuse but very luminous sources of X-ray radiation. X-ray telescopes have to be in space because X-rays do not travel very far in Earth's atmosphere; focusing X-rays is technically fairly difficult, so the first X-ray telescope that could create images were launched by NASA in the late 1970s. When astronomers realized that the X-ray radiation was being generated by hot gas in between the galaxies, they at first thought they had found the mysterious dark matter. This gas is so diffuse that it is invisible in visible light, but is very obvious in X-ray observations. However, this initial interpretation was quickly dashed: while this gas outweighs the stars by about a factor of 7, this fell well short of the factor of 50 needed to explain dark matter.

However, this gas "feels" dark matter's gravity. In fact, without dark matter's gravity, this gas (like the galaxies) would quickly diffuse and become invisible. By measuring the density, temperature, and location of this gas, we get clues about the density and location of the dark matter.

We have two completely independent ways to measure the hot gas. One is using X-ray telescopes (like NASA's Chandra telescope) and the other is using ground-based submm telescopes. These submm telescopes "see" the hot gas in clusters of galaxies by taking advantage of a physical process called the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect or SZE. In brief, we are surrounded on all sides by low-energy photons, best seen in the sub-millimeter range, coming from the Big Bang. This radiation is known as the cosmic background radiation. When a background photon passes through a cluster of galaxies, it can interact with an electron in the hot gas, and the interaction changes the energy (or wavelength) of the photon. So clusters of galaxies show up as rare and subtle "shadows" against the cosmic background radiation. The depth of the shadow is proportional to the gas pressure of the gas. Because we have two independent measurements, the analyses of both measurements gives us more accurate constraints on the density and location of the hot gas, and therefore, the concentration and location of the dark matter.

The clusters we are studying were also studied by a significant Hubble Space Telescope project, called CLASH for Cluster Lensing And Supernovae with Hubble. These 25 clusters are perfectly sited in the universe for our study: they are massive and far enough to be easily studied with SZE telescopes, but close enough and luminous enough to be studied with X-ray telescopes.


I played a small role in this project, as an X-ray expert. My role was to prepare and analyze the X-ray data in support of this project, and provide an external test site for software installation and performance. I use a local, shared-use science cluster at Michigan State University called the High Performance Computing Cluster. It is Linux-based, and bears many key similarities to the clusters used by the PI, Jack Sayers, at Caltech. I was supported for two weeks over each of the last two years to complete this work. I will continue working with the extended project to support the writing of a paper and to provide advice and materials for the PI's outreach efforts to local schools.
